div.div: First off, my apologies if anyone had difficulty accessing the first several minutes of the live stream of the School Board meeting last night. We've ironed out the glitches and should be in good shape going forward.

Quick recap: the agenda items preceding the budget took longer than expected, so around 9:45 pm, Chair Linda Owen (who deftly managed our first Zoom meeting!) wisely suggested that we reconvene on Thursday to focus just on our financial plans for FY21. If you have the time, please join us at 6 pm on our Facebook page. You can also send in public comments (which will be read at the meeting) tospeakers@rvaschools.net. Thank you!
Before getting to the rest of today's topics, I just wanted to say...Happy Birthday, Mom!
Shout-outs!Please keep sending them to me atjkamras@rvaschools.net!

li.em: Huge Shout out to theBosuhall CIS Team (Hannah & Taylor)and severalBoushall staff! They have been supporting scholars all year, but their support during the COVID-19 has been above and beyond. It includes conducting weekly virtual meetings with scholars; delivering food as well as hygiene and household supplies to families without transportation; reaching out through dailyemails, texts and phone calls to scholars regarding RPS@Home, Chromebooks, etc.; assisting with community food distribution from our campus; and working on the Bosuhall/CISGratitude Campaign, which is a mindfulness project. WAY TO GO, EAGLES!

I wanted to say how awesome theparents and students of Huguenot High Schoolhave been over the past week. They have shown great respect for social distancing, amazing patience with the distribution process, and a great deal of kindness to the volunteers and workers. A special shout out to10th grader Jalilah Goodenandher mother Mrs. Hicksfor bringing the workers coffee and Chick-fil-A gift cards for lunch. It is an honor and pleasure to serve such a wonderful community.

A heartfelt thank you toRichmond Communityparents,Christoph and CopelandCasati, who deliveredover 250 masks toJohn Marshallfor familiesthat came to pick up Chromebooks. Each family that received a mask today was grateful and it was greatly appreciated!

Shout out to the Counseling Team,Mrs. Johnson, Mrs. Torres & Mr. Parker,atBoushall Middle Schoolfor doing awesome work with our scholars: holding a Virtual Boushall Eagle Meeting with scholars, e- counselingsessions with families, and e-mentoring sessions with AMP! scholars; and creating an online bilingual counseling newsletter with resources and sign-up links for more assistance. You are what holds our family together.You are #EAGLEEXCELLENT!

I would like to shout-outCorinne Harrigan(security officer atArmstong). She was extremely helpful today. I explained that I was there to get work packets for many of the students in the Rainbow community. I needed ten work packets for each subject per grade level, which was a lot. Ms. Harrigan was very pleasant and patient. She took the time to pack everything in boxes for me. Thank you, Ms. Harrigan, for goingabove and beyond to make sure I had everything I needed for the students. You are truly appreciated.

I would like to give a personal shout out toMs. Rahmah JohnsonatThomas Jefferson High School. My son is a senior and I would NOT have been able to navigate through his senioritis, remaining course work, and post-high school plans without her. This transitionhas been smooth onlybecauseof her. Ms. Rahmah, it is a blessing to know that we have someone in our corner that understands our child, his needs, his strengths, and his weaknesses, as well as the inner-workings of the district with the ever-changing new normal that we are dealing with...Thanks for the letters, the calls, and the advice. Go, Vikings!

I would like to send a shout out toPrincipal Shawand thewonderful staffatMiles Jones Elementary Schoolfor being a food distribution site. In addition, I would like to give a special thank you to my daughter's Fourth Grade Teacher,Chelsie Smith(Room 208), for going above and beyond with her students. Ms. Smith has held a Zoom meeting weekly, only missing a session when her grandfather passed and she traveled from Virginia to Ohio and back again! She deserves the teacher of the year award!

I would like to shout outMs. Sharonda Ware, a math interventionist fromOverby-Sheppard. She has received a large donation from DonorsChoose to provide additional supplies for her students. She has been at home putting goody bags together for students. In addition, she makes house calls to provide food for families that do not have transportation.

Wanted to say a huge thank you to 3rd grade teacher atFox Elementary,Ms. Eck! Shes been in constant contact with her class via Zoom meetings, google classroom, read-a-louds, and endless additional resources she has been giving to her class! We appreciate you, Ms. Eck!

I'd love to shout outCynthia Reyes,President of the PTA atE.S.H. Greene Elementary School. For years, she has been a great advocate for the Latino community across the Richmond area, helping to improve their quality of life and working with different organizations to fight for their rights.

Thank you toMs. SchwarzfromMary Munford. She is my sons fourth grade teacher and she has continued to meet with her class daily and provide instruction. My son is grateful for the opportunity to see his teacher and classmates.

Thank you toMs. Robinson, a first grade teacher fromOverby-Sheppard. She has mailed resources to parents and talks to the kids on a regular basis. She is awesome! Thank you toMs. Carruthers, a fifth grade teacher at Overby-Sheppard. She mailed a personal letter to her students. The kids loved it and appreciated the fact that she misses them.

I would like to shout outMr. WyattatBinford Middle School. He was my daughters civics teacher last year, and he has always been amazing. He wished her a happy birthday this year even though she has moved on to high school. He posts current events and links it to the study of civics and government on a regular basis. He really brings learning to life.
I want to shout out my awesome school counselor,Ms. Salena Scott, for helping promote the New STEM AcademyatMLK!

Big shout out toMs. Johnson and Ms.Thompsons parents (BlackwellPre-K Inclusion) who woke up early on Saturday to morning to allow their pre-k children to ZOOM with their teachers for Saturday breakfast.
Shout-out to theteachers and staffatPatrick Henryfor putting together a lovely collage (below) for their students!

div.div: 2020 Census Have you filled out your census form yet? If not, please do so ASAP! Now, more than ever, we need EVERYONE in our community counted, as the census will have huge implications for education funding over the next 10 years. Need further inspiration? Listen to our 2019 National Teacher of the Year, Mr. Rodney Robinson!

New RPS Support Line (804-780-6195) As I shared yesterday, weve created a hotline so that RPS families can quickly get answers (in English or Spanish) about food and technology distribution, housing support, transportation, language assistance, Pre-K and Kindergarten registration, and more. See the flyers below!
Computer Distribution Here's all the info you need for this week:

div.strong: Which students will receive computers and hot-spots this week?

ul.li: This week is for anyRPS9th or 10th grader whoalreadysigned up for a device using the online form AND any senior or 11th grader who signed up but was unable to come on their original distribution date.
If you have not signed up yet, you can do sohere.

div.strong: When will middle school and elementary school students receive their computers and hot-spots?

ul.li: As soon as we're done with high school students, we'll move on to middle school and elementary school students. Thank you for your patience!

div.strong: Where do I go to pick up my computer and/or hot-spot?

ul.li: Armstrong HS (for high school students from Armstrong and Franklin Military)
Huguenot HS (forhigh school students from Huguenot only)
Marshall HS (for high school students from Marshall, Community, TJ, Open, RAS, and RCEEA)
Wythe HS (forhigh school students from Wythe only)
Note: Please make every effort to go to your assigned location as we have a set number of devices for each school based on the survey.
9th Graders: Thursday, April 23
If you're a 10th-12th grader and you weren't able to make your original distribution date, you can come on Thursday.
9:30 am (for last names starting with the letters A-D)
10:15 am (for last names starting with the letters E-J)
11:00 am(for last names starting with the letters K-R)
11:45 am (or last names starting with the letters S-Z)

Note: These time windows are intended to help with social distancing so we respectfully request that students do everything possible to adhere to them. That said, we will not turn away anyone who comes outside their designated time.

div.strong: What do I need to bring?

ul.li: We need a parent/caregiver to sign our standard user agreement, available inEnglishandSpanish. If a parent/caregiver cannot come, a student may come on their own as long as they bring a signed agreement with them. These forms will be available at all of the computer pick-up sites, and you can also get them from ourwebsiteand ourfood sites.
Your student ID# (which can be found on your report card and transcript)
A mask or face covering
Each distribution site will have two pick-up options: in the building and curbside.

The process of signing out a computer and/or hotspot will take about 15 minutes per student. Each device needs to be powered up and the student then needs to log in to make sure everything is working properly. Parents/caregivers may come without their student but they will need to be able to log on with their student's ID# and password. Given this, we strongly encourage students to come.
Everyone on the distribution team will be wearing masks and gloves, and will have disinfectant wipes for the devices and hand sanitizer for anyone who needs it.

div.div: "Mr. K's 30 Minutes of Math!" Check outmy math lessons at 2 pm every weekdays. I'm focusing on fractions, but every lesson also includes a Math Joke of the Day and a Math Riddle of the Day. You can alsoview past episodes here!
Important Links I'll note inorangewhen there have been additions/updates so you you won't miss anything.

span.p: - Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, and help young children do the same. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.
- Wash your hands especiallyafter coughing and sneezing, before and aftercaring for an ill person, and beforepreparing foods and before eating.
- Cover your nose and mouth with a tissuewhen you cough or sneeze and then throw the tissue in the trash.
- Avoid close contact(such as kissing, sharing cups, or sharing eating utensils)with people who are sick.
- Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects, such as toys and doorknobs, especially if someone is sick.
- Stay home when you are sick, except when you need to get medical care.
